title: Domain 2.1: Compare and contrast common threat actors and motivations.
content:
ðŸŽ­ Threat Actors

  • Nation-state: Government-sponsored, highly skilled, and well-funded. Goals: cyber-espionage, sabotage, and national defense.
  • Script kiddie: Unskilled attacker using pre-made tools. Low sophistication, but still dangerous.
  • Hacktivist: Politically or socially motivated attacker. Focused on disruption, defacement, and leaks.
  • Insider threat: Authorized user misusing accessâ€”can be accidental or malicious.
  • Organized crime: Profit-focused and structured. Known for ransomware, identity theft, and fraud.
  • Shadow IT: Employees using unauthorized tech or apps that bypass security policies.

ðŸ§¬ Attributes of Threat Actors

  • Internal vs. External: Internal actors are within the org (employees); external actors are outside (hackers, competitors).
  • Resources/Funding: The more resources, the more advanced the attack. Nation-states and crime groups rank highest.
  • Level of Sophistication: Can range from phishing and malware to zero-day exploits and social engineering.

ðŸŽ¯ Motivations

  • Data exfiltration: Stealing sensitive info for resale, extortion, or espionage.
  • Espionage: Secret surveillance or theft of strategic info (corporate or national).
  • Service disruption: Interrupts business (e.g., via DDoS or ransomware).
  • Blackmail: Threatens to release/destroy data unless paid.
  • Financial gain: Main driver for cybercrimeâ€”fraud, ransomware, and theft.
  • Philosophical/political beliefs: Hacktivists attacking based on causes or ideologies.
  • Ethical: White-hats exposing vulnerabilities to improve security (e.g., bug bounty hunters).
  • Revenge: Angry insiders or former employees seeking retaliation.
  • Disruption/chaos: Some act for fun, recognition, or anarchyâ€”often unskilled or thrill-seeking.
  • War: Cyberwarfare to disrupt infrastructure or gain strategic advantage.
